note: First peak of a double-peaked flare from AR 3654, as observed in SDO AIA 131.
Second peak of a double-peaked flare from AR 3654, as observed in SDO AIA 131.

Flare is determined to occur from AR 3654, presently around the west limb. Longitude of W100 is pulled from the Magnetic Connectivity Solarscape Viewer, with AR 3654's estimated location at this time around the limb.
With contribution from AR 3664
with contribution from AR 3664
With contribution from Active Region 3664
With a large contribution from Active Region 3663.
With contribution from Active Region 3663
First peak of a double peaked flare from AR 3663. Immediately followed by an M4.3-class flare which peaked at 2024-05-06T22:27Z
Second peak of a double peaked flare from AR 3663. Preceded by an M1.2-class flare which peaked at 2024-05-06T21:48Z.
Simultaneous flaring with AR 3668 (flare centered at S18E11) at this same time, association given to AR 3663 with the brighter signature of the two regions in SDO AIA 131.
Simultaneous flaring with AR 3668, but separate distinct peaks (this flare is the first peak) seen in SDO AIA 131.
Simultaneous flaring with AR 3663, but separate distinct peaks (this flare is the second peak) seen in SDO AIA 131. End time is manually calculated from start and peak flux values.
First peak of a double peaked flare from AR 3663. Immediately followed by an M1.0-class flare which peaked at 2024-05-07T13:35Z.
Second peak of a double peaked flare from AR 3663. Immediately preceded by an M1.0-class flare which peaked at 2024-05-07T13:25Z.

There is simultaneous flaring from Active Region 13668 at the time of this event. However, a majority of the flaring activity occurs from Active Region 13664, and was associated with this flare for that reason.

X-ray flux was previously elevated to M-class background levels by the preceding M2.1 flare peaking at 2024-05-07T20:22Z from Active Region 13664. This M1.2 flare corresponds to flaring visible from Active Region 13664 as seen in SDO AIA 131 imagery. Multiple small peaks were observed by GOES X-ray flux, but all of these 'bumps' correspond to the M1.2 flare stated in this entry. Due to simultaneous flaring from Active Region 13663, this event partially overlaps with the M3.3 flare peaking at 2024-05-07T21:26Z. The end time was therefore based on the start time of the subsequent M3.3 flare.
This flare partially overlaps with the preceding M3.3 flare peaking at 2024-05-07T21:26Z. Simultaneous, less intense flaring is also observed from Active Region 13664 at the time of this event.

X-ray flux was previously elevated to M-class background levels due to the preceding M3.3 flare peaking at 2024-05-07T21:59Z from Active Region 13663. This flare entry corresponds to flaring activity observed from Active Region 13664 as seen in SDO AIA 131 imagery. There are previous 'bumps' observed in GOES X-ray flux occurring prior to this event that do not correspond to flaring activity beyond the elevated background levels.

An M3.5 flare also from Active Region 13664 immediately precedes this X1.0 flare. Both flares may be considered to be associated with the eruptive activity observed in UV imagery and the coronal mass ejection observed in SOHO LASCO, however, analysis is ongoing.
Simultaneous brightening seen in UV imagery from Active Region 13663 (N25W65) may have contributed to the peak flux of this flare.
Simultaneous brightening seen in UV imagery from Active Region 13664 (S22W15) may have contributed to the peak flux of this flare.
Overlaps with subsequent flaring from Active Region 13664.
Overlapping flaring from Active Region 13663 may have contributed to the flux of the flare, particularly before the peak of this M8.5 flare.
First peak of a double peaked flare. Times adjusted to match NOAA SWPC Solar & Geophysical Activity Summary.
Second of double peaked flare. Times based off of NOAA SWPC Solar & Geophysical Activity Summary.

X-ray flux was previously elevated to M-class background levels by preceding X1.0 flare from Active Region 13664 peaking at 2024-05-08T21:40Z. This M1.8 flare corresponds to flaring activity from Active Region 13664 which produces multiple 'bumps' observed in GOES X-ray flux, with the peak being the M1.8 value listed in this entry.

X-ray flux was previously elevated to M-class background levels following the preceding M4.5 flare peaking at 2024-05-09T03:32Z and M1.7 flare peaking at 2024-05-09T04:49Z, both from Active Region 13664. End time based on visual inspection of GOES X-ray flux compared to SDO AIA 131 imagery of flaring activity from Active Region 13664 at the time of this event.
X-ray flux was previously elevated to M-class background levels following the M2.4 flare from Active Region 13664 peaking at 2024-05-09T06:27Z.

Simultaneous, less intense flaring also occurs from Active Region 13663 at the time of this event. This M2.1 flare overlaps with following X2.2 flare peaking at 2024-05-09T09:13Z, also from Active Region 13664.

X-ray flux was previously elevated following the M3.7 flare from Active Region 13664 peaking at 2024-05-09T13:23Z. Minor brightening from Active Region 13664 corresponds to this M1.0 flare. The end time was estimated based on visual inspection of GOES X-ray flux compared to imagery from SDO AIA 131 at the time of this event.
This flare occurred from an unnumbered region near/slightly beyond the eastern limb.
Flaring beyond NE limb.
Currently unnumbered region, simultaneous flaring from AR13664 (S20W74).
Simultaneous flaring from AR13675 and unnumbered region near S10E90+ on/beyond the eastern limb.
First peak in a bumpy double-peaked flare, both of which precede a larger, long-duration M4.9 and M6.6 peaked flare from the same eruption from AR 3664.
Second peak in a bumpy double-peaked flare, both of which precede a larger, long-duration M4.9 and M6.6 peaked flare from the same eruption from AR 3664.

Second largest peak in a long-duration eruption/flare from Active Region 13664. Small peaks in GOES X-ray flux are observed within this long duration flare, but appear to correspond to the same eruption. These peaks include an M1.2, M1.4, and M4.9 flare peaking at 2024-05-13T08:20Z, 2024-05-13T08:29Z, and 2024-05-13T09:33Z respectively.
Largest peak in a long-duration eruption/flare from Active Region 13664. Additional brightening from S18W80, a northern portion of AR 3664, contributed to the peak X-ray flux value.
This flare primarily occurs from Active Region 13676 but simultaneous, less intense flaring also occurs from Active Region 13664.
Directly preceding a X1.7 flare from AR 3664. Some simultaneous brightening observed in SDO AIA 131 at AR 3670 (N20W22), but the signature at AR 3664 is significantly brighter.
Small flare compared to background, manually calculated end time. Originally entered to support a CME, which was later determined to be unrelated. No need to delete this entry, though.
This flare occurs near/slightly beyond the western limb, but likely originates from former Active Region 13664.
AR 3664 is likely ~S19W96 at this time, but W90 used as we cannot determine this yet.
Active Region 3685 was numbered on 2024-05-16. Could be the return of old AR 3654, which had several M-class flares (including an M9.5) on its previous rotation.
Active Region 3685 was numbered on 2024-05-16. Could be the return of old AR 3654, which had several M-class flares (including an M9.5) on its previous rotation.
Active Region 3685 was numbered on 2024-05-16. Could be the return of old AR 3654, which had several M-class flares (including an M9.5) on its previous rotation.
Active region is likely to old AR3664 based on solar rotation calculation.
Simultaneous flaring from AR13695 (N28E36).
Simultaneous flaring from AR13697.
Follows shortly after the X1.4 flare also from AR13679. Start time determined using visual inspection of the GOES-P X-ray flux timeline and SDO AIA 131 imagery.
Simultaneous brightening from AR13697 (still decaying from X1.4 and M5.9 flares).
